results.headline: Getting to Know a Serial Killer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Jeffrey Dahmer Files

results.summary_short: Chris James Thompson’s documentary uses restraint to explore about the skin-crawling crimes of Jeffrey Dahmer from three wildly different — yet equally intimate — perspectives.

results.headline: Try Freedom: Less Filling! Tastes Great!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of NO

results.summary_short: The campaign to remove Pinochet from rule in Chile becomes an advertiser’s job in “No,” with Gael García Bernal.

results.headline: Just Another Deal Becomes Complicated

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Like Someone in Love

results.summary_short: “Like Someone in Love” is a complicated triangle involving a prostitute, her pimp and a john.

results.headline: The Mother Country Knows Best

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shanghai Calling

results.summary_short: In “Shanghai Calling” a haughty Chinese-American corporate lawyer gets his comeuppance when he is sent to China to work on a big deal.

results.headline: The Man Who Protected Lincoln

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Saving Lincoln

results.summary_short: In “Saving Lincoln” Salvador Litvak tells the story of Lincoln’s de facto bodyguard, using a process that puts actors into virtual sets created from vintage Civil War photographs.

results.headline: Three’s Company, Twice Over

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Almost in Love

results.summary_short: In mostly two unbroken takes Sam Neave’s “Almost in Love” looks at three friends whose relationships are strained by love and sex.

results.headline: Threatened by Foe and Friend

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Berlin File

results.summary_short: An arms deal gone sour lifts the lid on a rat’s nest of espionage for a North Korean spy who’s been left out in the cold in “The Berlin File.”

results.headline: Her Date Is a Single Dad; His, a Possible Killer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Safe Haven

results.summary_short: The romantic thriller “Safe Haven” is the eighth film adaptation of a Nicholas Sparks novel.

results.headline: Ding, Dong! The Witch Is Cute

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Beautiful Creatures

results.summary_short: “Beautiful Creatures” has sweet young things and supernatural shenanigans.

results.headline: When Action Is the Family Business
results.display_title: A Good Day to Die Hard

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Good Day to Die Hard

results.summary_short: Bruce Willis takes his fifth turn playing John McClane, this time in Moscow, in the stunt-loaded film “A Good Day to Die Hard.”

results.headline: Zany Quest for Laughs, the Chinese Version

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lost in Thailand

results.summary_short: “Lost in Thailand” reteams the actors Xu Zheng and Wang Baoqiang in their cross-country odd-couple shtick from the 2010 hit “Lost on Journey.”

results.headline: Suburban Perfection, With Warts

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Playroom

results.summary_short: “The Playroom” is a drama about a seemingly ideal family in the 1970s that has several cracks below the surface.

results.headline: May Cause Greed, Lust or Retirement

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Side Effects

results.summary_short: Steven Soderbergh’s “Side Effects” follows twists and turns involving a fictitious antidepressant (which has its own real Web site).

results.headline: A Movie Has No Plot. So What?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Once Every Day

results.summary_short: In “Once Every Day,” the avant-garde playwright Richard Foreman confounds moviegoers’ expectations about narrative and offers patterns and themes instead.

results.headline: No Ordinary Trip to Grandma’s House

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lore

results.summary_short: In “Lore,” which is not a fairy tale but feels like one, five children cross Germany in 1945.

results.headline: Clinging to His Non-mainstream Identity
results.display_title: A Rubberband Is an Unlikely Instrument

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Rubberband Is an Unlikely Instrument

results.summary_short: The documentary “A Rubberband Is an Unlikely Instrument” follows a Brooklyn musician who plays in the subway and would rather buy a rare guitar than medical insurance.

results.headline: A Truculent Man in a Wheelchair and a Diaper

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Porfirio

results.summary_short: “Porfirio,” a sort of documentary-fiction hybrid by Alejandor Landes, has a script, but the story is that of its subject-actor, a paraplegic in Colombia with a startling past.

results.headline: Past, Present, Future, All at the Same Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Night Across the Street

results.summary_short: “Night Across the Street,” the final film from the director Raúl Ruiz, focuses on a young boy in love with cinema.

results.headline: A Woman Who Unleashes Her Inner Medusa on an Everyman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Identity Thief

results.summary_short: In “Identity Thief” Melissa McCarthy plays Diana, who wreaks havoc on a milquetoast, Sandy Patterson (Jason Bateman), by stealing his credit cards and more.

results.headline: A Beat-Generation Star Who Won’t Answer to the Name

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ferlinghetti: A Rebirth of Wonder

results.summary_short: The documentary “Ferlinghetti: A Rebirth of Wonder” looks at the poet Lawrence Ferlinghetti, publisher of Allen Ginsberg and a founder of the City Lights bookstore in San Francisco.
